A world class ski resort that keeps getting better. Great slopes and fast, comfortable chair lifts. 3 days is a perfect amount to get your fix of skiing and still leave many of the runs unexplored.

My only gripe is the exorbitant costs to get there. There needs to be better parking or shuttle service.

review_text: Great resort, kids had a great time. Awesome instructor's. Only problem was trying to find meeting point or any kind of guidance on arrival,asked lots of staff for direction, obviously no training given to staff . You have to fend for yourself. Lost alot of time.

review_text:
Great place for a snow board/ski.
The downside is that the resorts on the mountain are expensive.

name: Shelly Fern
review_text: The lift tickets are VERY pricey (comparable to Vail or Aspen, Colorado) so much so one would think the resort would have modern equipment and chalets.. The chairlifts are from many decades ago (plastic teal slats with no padding or footbars) and are so uncomfortable and slow it was unbelievable. There are two high speed chairs lifts and more T bar lifts than I have ever seen. The chalets remind me of the first chalets I visited from the 80s in the hills of small towns. The entire experience was a blast from the past.  I suppose when you are one of the only resorts in the country to ski there isn't a priority to update/improve the infrastructure.

I was pleased to not have to pay access to National park because I was a pensioner. Lots of people on ski lifts etc. not really crowded so everyone could enjoy.

name: Kath Angus
review_text: Good facilities, good snow. Great lifties, especially when they dance. Night skiing is fun but look out for heroes being sketchy on the slopes.

name: Vijay Solomon
review_text: Enjoyed the atmosphere and it was damn cold when I reached at 6. Toboggan entertainment was the best paart and food was good at kebab .

name: Abby Deniz
review_text: Absolute rip off a mountain. $100 train ride to the mountain then $160 for day tickets. Never again will I ski Australia again. I'll happily take my money overseas like I do anyway. Just had to try it. Good overall runs to ski on but they are just milking us Aussies big time!

name: Billy Latino (BlyLtn)
review_text: Great place for some slope fun. Lil pricey and crowded at times but still had a good time

name: Paul Higginbotham
review_text: I'm sure all kids are different but the beginner class for my 3 and 5 year old was not worth the money.

name: Allan Angeles
review_text: Love the snow... it's snow time!

name: umber raza
review_text: Great

name: Matt M
review_text:
The whole resort has not changed in 20 years and shows it. 5 hours of travel for a second rate resort. Inadequate parking, substandard facilities, no lift line organization, very expensive prices for everything - accommodation, lift tickets, food, you name it it's 3 times normal price.
So high I wont be coming back as its now better value flying overseas to places like Canada, where they know how to run ski resorts.
The stranglehold the National parks has on everything is killing it. Good luck.

name: Amanda Cito
review_text: Awesome, but expensive food, drinks and passes

name: Alexander Favero
review_text: Best skiing in Australia but still not much snow early season, had to re-visit in August because there was no snow for our visit in July. Nice food at the 'Mid Station' restaurant, would recommend the Aspen Fries.

name: Oakley van Didden
review_text: Gear place to ski and really fun!!

name: Hazel Key
review_text: Great skiing, well prepared runs. But their food outlets are expensive and the food quality not so great - fried food galore!

name: Christopher Greenough
review_text: Brilliant!!!

name: David Cleworth
review_text: My favourite Australian ski resort, because it is accessible to a wide range of people with many choices for access. There are slopes that face in many directions so there is a slope for every occasion, and the friendly operators manage access to suit the prevailing snow conditions. There are Lodges and accomodation on site and a range of budget facilities across the field from Perisher, Smiggins, Guthega and Bluecow that will suit anyone and when all connecting lifts are running a wide ranging adventure is possible with a week of exploring and fun on offer. Great fun and adventure.

name: Brad H
review_text:
Great place to ski for all levels of skier/boarder. Tonnes of groomers to shred and when there's snow the off-piste is on-point! You're not gonna have the massive vertical mountain experience of some NA or European resorts but there's just so much ground to cover here you'll never be bored. Take a short 5-10min side country hike and you'll be hitting freshies for the whole day.

The Terrain Parks are some of the best in the world with lots of options for beginners all the way up to those massive triple XL's they keep on front valley, a small and large half-pipe just for the icing on the cake.

name: Simon Lee
review_text: If you love the snow, you should be here

name: KANAV MANCHANDA

review_text:
Perisher ski resort is a massive but good ski resort. They offer a convenient ski tube from bullocks flat to Perisher to Blue Cow.
Fantastic facilities all over the resort including bathrooms, restaurants, bars, ski and snowboard hire and accommodation. There is something here for everyone.  It is also pretty easy to access. Friendly staff and every one is here to have a good time. Totally recommend for your next winter holiday.

name: william adams
review_text: EXTREMELY DISAPPOINTED IN MANAGEMENT AT PERISHER!!!!! I Have bought a seasons pass for 3 years in a row now. My wife was pregnant and we found out at 24 weeks that she had preeclampsia which then developed to HELLP syndrome. This in short started to shut down her body as her liver was failing. The doctors had to deliver our baby boy at 26weeks in order to save her and his life and he is currently in the Neonatal intensive care unit and will be for sometime. I contacted PERISHER and told them situation and said I can get a letter from the hospital regarding this. I Asked them if I could extend my seasons pass to next year as i will be by his side in hospital everyday and will not be able to go down at all. THEY SAID NO. I ASKED FOR A CREDIT NOT A REFUND! VERY DISAPPOINTED!!

name: Kia Mehr
review_text:
Please read ****
It's sad that I have to write this review.
I've been long long term skier at Perisher me and my family and friends but none of us are going back after last weekend .
Simply after waiting in Wentworth TBat like for 25min
I was pushed away and rejected the ride just because I was a single rider , I understand that it's  busy and it's good for everyone to ride double but I tried and I couldn't find a single to ride but it's not written anywhere that u can't ride and u deserve to be pushed away when ur a single rider .
The girls name was Sarah and I told her I will complain and she laughed at me and told me good luck .
I went straight to the office and I was promised a phone call from the manager now it's been over a week and I haven't received a call .
It's u sad for them to loose over 7 riders who ride every second week at Perisher over a very poor costumer service .
Very disappointed.
Don't go to Perisher

review_text:
I didn't stay in the resort however my family and I went to The Perisher ski resort to see snow for the first time, we used the snow slopes for tobogganing which was an amazing time and we used the chair lifts to just take a look around.
There is a ranger gate house on the Kosciuszko road where you can buy your national park vehicle pass the day pass cost us $29. There is a cost to use the chairlifts, a shop to hire any snow sporting accessories or extra snow clothes. If you are in a 4 wheel drive, chains are not needed but it is by law 2wheel drives have to carry snow chains but there is plenty of places in Jindabyne you can hire them from.
Would definitely recommend this place.

name: Ian Su
review_text: Perisher Shi Nan Ban Qiu Ye Shi Ao Zhou Zui Da Qie Re Men De Xue Chang,Han Gua Perisher,Smiggin,Blue Cow,GuthegaSi Ge Shan Tou,Chu Zhong Gao Jie Du You Shi He Xue Dao Ke Wan,Tui Jian GuthegaQu Yu Feng Jing Mei,Alpine EyreXu Hui La T-BARCai Neng Chi De Han Bao Dian,Mei Zhou Er,Liu De Ye Hua Huan You Yan Huo,Xue Chang Yong Ji Ming Gan Ying Shi Qia Pian Fang Bian,Ye Ke Shang Wang Huo Xia Zai AppKan Zi Ji Hua Xue Lan Che Ji Lu,Que Dian Xue Dao Du Pian Duan,Xue Piao Jia Ge Ye Pian Gui,Bi Kai Ao Zhou Lian Jia Lai Ba.
review_translated_text: Perisher is the largest and most popular ski resort in the Southern Hemisphere and Australia. It encompasses four mountain peaks: Perisher, Smiggin, Blue Cow, and Guthega. There are trails suitable for beginners, intermediate, and advanced skiers. We recommend Guthega for its beautiful scenery and Alpine Eyre for its T-bar-style burger joint. There are night skiing and fireworks every Tuesday and Saturday. The resort uses contactless cards for convenience, and you can also check your ski lift history online or download an app. The downside is that the trails are relatively short and the ski passes are expensive, so avoid visiting during long Australian holidays.

name: Kaye Chapman
review_text:
Largest ski resort in Australia with a mix of easy, moderate and difficult runs. Most runs are easy and the more difficult terrain opens later in the season July/August.

Food is expensive so I I recommend bringing your own. Day pass is expensive so plan ahead and get a season pass at the end of the year September/October for the best deals.

Pro tip - Bluecow is the best place for beginners.

name: Emiliano Tiscornia
review_text:
Biggest ski resort in the southern hemisphere, 47 lifts in total. Lots of tracks to ride for beginners and advanced alike. Beautiful place in it's own right.
Would not recommend to rent the gear in the resort if you are under a tight budget. There are several places in Jindabyne (small town 20min away from the resort). Also, bringing your own food for lunch is always an option. Menus offered are not very healthy and quite expensive.
Mind that if you drive to Perisher Valley having chains in your trunk is mandatory in case of snowy days. You can rent chains in petrol stations in Jindabyne

review_text: Feel so lucky every time we get to stay here. The management are lovely, the proximity to the slopes to die for and the food on another level. The entertainment this year was also amazing, the young talented pianist, guitarist and singer - was also carrying our suitcases the next day. This time around we got an upgrade to a suite - had to pinch ourselves. Great place to stay if you have the $ and the inclination to ski in Australia!

name: Manusha Hewage
review_text: Perisher (known as Perisher Blue until 2009) is the largest ski resort in the Southern Hemisphere.[1] Located in the Australian Snowy Mountains, the resort is an amalgamation of four villages (Perisher Valley, Smiggin Holes, Guthega, and Blue Cow) and their associated ski fields, covering approximately 12 square kilometres (5 sq mi), with the base elevation at 1,720 metres (5,640 ft) AHD, and the summit elevation of 2,054 metres (6,739 ft) at the top of Mount Perisher. 4.4 square kilometres (1.7 sq mi) of this area is covered by 240 snow guns, which are used to artificially supplement the natural snowfall.

When we visited Snowy Mountains we stayed at Cooma because it's a lot cheaper than Jindabyne. But it's up to your personal preferences of which area you'd like to stay.
Also, the Perisher Ski Resort parking can be packed to prepared to walk a little and do some sight seeing.

name: Sheridan B
review_text:
Unfortunately Perisher seems to be way too focused on profits. They do not re-invest into making the resort better. Certain chairlifts are very old, slow and do not carry many people. These need replacing with newer, faster ones to get people where they need to go. Additionally, there are way too many T-bars which makes much of the resort inaccessible for beginners and snowboarders.

Retail and food outlets are very pricey. The best deal on the mountain was the $2 hot chocolate up at mid- station each morning til 10am. First tracks and night skiing are great and its fantastic that these are free with your Epic Australia pass.

Skitube is a convenient way to get up to Perisher each day, however, this is also quite expensive even if you add it onto your season pass. We were also disappointed that the skitube stopped running during October even though the ski lifts were still open. This made it very difficult to access the resort.

Overall, Perisher needs to invest in improving facilities, replacing old/ slow chairlifts and improve access to areas which are currently T-bar only.

name: N Armstrong
review_text: I have been to both Perisher and Thredbo and mid July to August is always the best time.  I have always had accommodation on the mountain however Thredbo was the best place to stay plus the choice of restaurants and other activities (large indoor pool for both winter and summer). Perisher at night has only have one pizza shop ( bad service no competition) or boring and expensive hotel food or simple lunch food /snacks cafe food.  The only challenge is Thredbo is lower in altitude and can become soft at the lower levels on sunny days. What I discovered by accident is Jindabyne is beautiful has a larger choice of restaurants compared to Thredbo ( plus has pool and cinema etc). It takes 10 min to drive to the ski tube from Jindabyne which takes you straight to Perisher ski resort, best of both worlds higher mountain and great village atmosphere at the end of the day.

name: Jamie Holyoak
review_text:
Perisher is a great resort with plenty of options on offer.

As the season progresses with more snow the more parks and features become available. I'd like to see a mini pipe again and a quarter pipe setup next season pls. The mini pipe is a great way to learn and get used to dropping in etc. The mid station location was perfect where it was a few years back. Quarter pipe could go in either park near front valley.

Parking is what it is, get there early and you won't have issues in busy times.

What is the area like to play in? Fantastic! So many options and if you wish you will never ski or board the same run in the one day. I usually start over at Eyre and work my way round to Guthega by end of the day and some final runs in Happy Valley, Copperhead Rd and home to front valley. The Superpipe is great when in along with each park area which has many features that work for all levels of skill. Perisher is a place where an advanced rider can find some decent challenging bespoke runs to some great beginner and progressive runs to help you transition into better on snow technique.

The beauty of Perisher is with many different facing aspects of ski areas you can normally find good snow somewhere on resort if you know where to look. Locals are friendly and happy to help in finding those areas of you are nice.

I've found Perisher to be one of the friendliest and good vibe snow fields anywhere I've been. Ski and board people get along mostly haha. It is what it is. But most people are nice and catch the vibe which can lead to great lift conversations and finding the good areas to hit first up.

The learner area is well setup with levels of progression even for learners. Only a good thing!

Mid Station is a great place as is blue cow for a beer and food. Normal resort prices like anywhere though. It costs money to get it all up there so cost is understandable I think.

Future wise what would I like to see?

Year pass separated into just Perisher and then the international one as another add on.

I'd like to see a cross country run like Copperhead Rd but from the top of mount P that runs around the back to Guthega. Used for Ski and board people of an advanced level.

On the transition trails between areas some off trail features would be cool too, like some small ramps etc as a pull over on the way trick for fun.

What would be the best addition? Joining forces with Charlotte's Pass and setting up a chair or gondola or extend the snow train out to Charlotte's so it opens even more up.

Facilities around Perisher, Blue Cow and Guthega are all dated but work well. 99% of the lift staff are great.

Getting to the snow from interstate is a challenge and it would be great to see Perisher advertise deals with Virgin or whoever for fly, drive, stay and ski packages through both Syd and Canberra. From the GC it would be great with a season pass to have a set rate to fly, drive or bus and accommodation at the snow. It would be a game changer.

Then I'd actually consider more weekend trips for a day of snow with travel either side.

I think all resorts, council and state gov need to extend the snow train to Jindy first and Cooma as a second option. It would bring more money and people into the region with them staying at Cooma and other towns on the way. Get Elon's Boring Company into it! A direct train connection out to Jindy from Canberra and Syd would also do nothing but bring more money into the region winter and summer.

review_text:
Still great snow cover with a solid base late in the season. Its been a while but good to be back. Prices are never going to be cheap (especially with kids) but its good to be sliding down the hill again, good for the soul.
If hiring try jindyabyne in the 1st instance..good gear and advice at competitive pricing (whilst you'll pay top dollar on the mount). We appreciated the help from Craig at Jindabyne sports and Jason from the Base (jindabyne). Jason was on the pulse for price and the complexity of our hire needs..be warned you will pay more... alot more to hire on the mount for the convenience.

review_text: Spent the weekend at Perisher. On Saturday they closed all the chairlifts in the morning in anticipation for windy conditions. However the morning was fine. They then opened the lifts in the afternoon when bthe wind picked up. Sunday was great with great weather. Jumpcam near mid station is amazing! Pictures are uploaded to dashboard instantly. Perisher has many chairlifts and alot of variety but could do with longer continuous runs and less flat sections that require traversing.

review_text: Perisher was great; lots of good snow, good machinery to get you up the mountain, and a decent priced holiday. HOWEVER, some of the staff were really rude. For example, when I was coming to the end of the chairlifts, I wasn't a very good snowboarder, so, instead of getting off the chairlifts from the ice that was in-front of me, I decided to get off at the side where there was good grip. Then, the person working at the top started shouting at me asking why I got off there. I said I didn't know where to get off and that I wasn't a good snowboarder, but he continued to shout at me.

name: Phillip Grasso
review_text:
Overpriced, some poor quality instructors, huge queues.

Overpriced: $111 for a child half day ticket!, $6 for a water, softdrink or hot chocolate. hotdog with chips ~$20.

Some good/great instructors, some terrible instructors. Some snowboard instructors especially handling the kids shouldn't have the title instructor. Kids spent 3 days in snowboard school and learned practically nothing. Watching from sidelines, snowboard instructors were too busy flirting with each other than teaching the kids.

Queues: V8, Quad, Summit Quad, pretty valley chair all packed to the max. Flowed ok with there was a coordinator packing the lines, but when there wasn't it ran slowly and sometimes waiting 30minutes to get on chair (in morning).

name: Rebecca Thompson
review_text: Perisher is by far the best ski resort in Australia. It is the largest ski resort (was once three ski resorts, but then they all combined to create Perisher). There is ample amounts of lifts, T-bars everywhere to keep you going all day. A wide variety of greens, blue and black runs to suit everyone. Allow time to get up the skitube from the bottom, as it takes approximately 30 minutes. Lots of restaurants scattered around the resort as well! Happily return here, as it's my favourite place to ski.

Only rated down one star as its super expensive & for some reason you can't hire tobogans on the mountain (?) Which is frustrating when you pick the kids up from ski school & they have their heart set on tobboganing for the afternoon - you have to hire them at Bullocks Flat or Jindabyne. Although some on-snow hotels have them available as well.

name: Monique Jenkins
review_text: My daughter, cousin and I spent the day at Perisher for some skiing. We had a great time overall, however some service areas could certainly do with some work. The hire centre at the bottom of the snow tube didn't have helpful staff at, compared with the staff at Thredbo who were very careful to properly fit skis and boots, and gave lots of tips for comfort. The runs at Perisher are lovely and far more expansive than Thredbo, but not always clearly marked which, particularly in heavy snow, can make navigation difficult. We frequently ended up around the backs of cabins and struggling to find the runs again. The lessons looked well run, and I like that the ski schools have a line for the lifts so xhildren can be added to lift groups, but unlike elsewhere the instructors didn't bother asking people if they minded helping the kids, and also didn't care that by forcibly pushing in they were separating my child from both of the adults she was with. Not acceptable. I will say though that the food court type area was great, with lots of options and friendly service. The runs were lovely and we will probably return, but hope to find better interpersonal skills from the staff next time.

They must have some portion where mothers can hang out special if there is a storm! Otherwise if I am single and ready to have some fun, I guess I would have given it 5 star. I love the place but I am a bit concerned about some if the changes since ownership changed.

I have experienced more chair lift issues this year than I can remember from previous years.

I have given up hope ever getting value from one of the resort's cafe's, after being stung almost $35 for 2 pies, a large chips and a Pepsi.

Fortunately there is a Woolies in Jindabyne so you can take a much cheaper lunch if you are staying in town.

I wonder if anyone has done the sums on how much more food they would sell if they were not gouging a captive market.

Virtually all food up the mountain contains gluten and/or dairy, which my partner can't eat, and this is annoying. Also why are the bread rolls inevitably the cheapest nastiest bread rolls ever, good bread rolls take up the same amount of space on a skidoo, stop price gouging on stupid things, I don't care if it's up the mountain if you want to charge $20 for a roll it had better be a good roll, until then I'll keep bringing my own food.

The skiing is good though. 4/5 stars, the fifth is on wind hold until they get the bread roll debacle sorted.

review_translated_text:
Older children and children under 125 cm cannot get on the lift unless they ask the person in charge for help, as the chair is higher than in Japan (^_^;)
For 8-seaters, the gate closes relatively quickly, so as soon as the gate opens, go forward and get on the conveyor belt to be carried near the lift waiting line. Proceed further to the red line and take the lift there. Turn away children who need help. If you have 8 people, you can get help if you stand on the far left and say one thing.
At the end of July 2018, there was snow all over the course, but there was less snow. There was rain and hail. According to the locals, the real season starts from August onwards.
Tickets are expensive and have your name engraved on a magnetic IC. The sensor's magnetism is strong, so I was warned not to bring my credit card close to it.
The slopes are quite gentle and are full of beginners, many of whom are Indian and Islanders who don't seem to be used to snow, so it's dangerous if you don't watch your surroundings while skiing.
The impression of the ski slope is similar to Sugadaira Kogen. There are no particularly high mountains in sight, and you can ski on all four mountains.

review_text: Perisher was great! Very easy to get around to the various runs, even as a first time skier. If possible go on a weekday and it'll be much less busy. There's shuttles between stops, otherwise you can get lifts and ski across.

name: jodi hurford
review_text:
Perisher is old and tired. It poorly lacks modern amenities and decent spaces for people to hang out comfortably in between runs. Everyone handles the outdated and cramped conditions for the sake of the beautiful snow.
The ski tube is an anitquated form of public transport, not worth the  $54 Persher charge for the round trip.
The train is like something you'd board in India; old and overcrowded.
For the amount of profit Perisher makes, it could reinvest in some badly needed and well overdue infrastructure.

name: James Mouat (Joffy)
review_text:
Resort coverage is large enough to get away from the crouds. Typically with a captive audience, prices are elevated but with a wide enough range of choices.
The resort itself combines four smaller resorts and features a large amount of lifts from the V8-Seater monster down to the carpark double, Tee bars (and Jay bars at Smiggins).
With the addition of snowguns and grooming the resort typically sees a good coverage, but when the wind comes in the outer limits of the resort (Perisher Mountain, Guthics and Blue Cow) shut down for safety.
Combine this with purpose built Jindabyne accomodation out at The Station and the SkiTube from Bullocks Flat, which is the best way to visit this resort daily.

And when the person who's sliding down, for sure will hit them down. Is there any way to put a visible warning sign for the toboggan rider? By that, the toboggan rider won't be get blame because of they hit down the people whose standing in the middle part of the tobbogan area.

review_text: Beautiful place, lots of good ski runs. In school holidays it can get crowded - with big queues for ski lifts, particularly if a bunch of lifts close due to strong winds. Could also use more areas for people to sit and have lunch. What's there gets jammed at lunchtime. And the food outlets mostly serve junk. Needs some better restaurants and cafes. I'd give 5 stars for the staff I encountered. Including two terrific ski instructors - Richard and Rich. Learnt heaps and enjoyed their classes. The Perisher website is a bit clunky, but works.

review_text: What's not to love, beautiful place, great people and lots of snowtastic adventures to be had by all. If you haven't been to the snow, I recommend you add it to your bucket list of things to do. Make sure you rug up and check the weather before packing. Layer / layer / layer :)

name: Warren Platts
review_text: Spent the last 6 days at Perisher on good snow under blue skies. I've never seen such good conditions for 6 consecutive days. The resort has plenty of ski runs for all levels from beginners up. There are several places to eat or grab a coffee all over the resort. They're all a bit pricey but I've come to expect that. For example, a large flat white coffee will set you back $6.90. All the staff on and off the snow that I have had anything to do with have been really nice. It's a great place to learn to ski for kids and adults alike. You can hire skis and boots etc there and there are plenty of shops at the main station to buy any ski apparel or accessories that you need. There is ski-in-ski-out accommodation available as well. I'll be going back in two weeks so if I think of anything else to add I will.

name: Francis
review_text: Perisher is absolutely huge. The pluses are it caters to all wants and needs and it is difficult to get bored as long as you're hitting the slopes, even after multiple visits - you'll be tired from exhaustion before you get tired of the mountain(s). The minuses are that it is expensive and it relies on a lot of t-bars to get around. But it should be part of the conversation when you are talking about the best snow resorts in the southern hemisphere.

review_text: Great place, Matt and the staff in the ticket office are fantastic. Brunelli's Cafe is just awesome! White Spider Restaurant for dinner is also awesome. Had a great weekend

name: Jake Pham
review_text: My friends and I snowboarded at Perisher for the last 7 days. We had 5 lessons with great, knowledgeable instructors who were really friendly. Office/sales staff have great customer service and are more than willing to help. On 3 occasions we were able to have our lessons changed from 9 to 11am due to arriving late from a dead car battery and stopping to put snow chains on. This was probably because it is not the peak season and there were still unbooked positions for the classes though. Lift operators were helpful with route recommendations and were friendly. I run blue trails and Perisher was more than fun and challenging enough for me. Outer Limits on Blue Cow had such good powder :O! Thredbo does seem to offer cheaper and more flexible lift and lesson packages, so I'll try it there next year and compare the routes.

It is a nice place to go to when you have kids. We went tobogganing, and there were plenty of large hills to toboggan off of, unlike in other resorts.

I suppose if I lived close by, I would give this 3 stars.

name: Jason Jones
review_text: Had a perfect blue bird day late in the season after lots of late snow. Drove straight up to main car park at about 8am managed to get a park in main carpark (3/4 full) Hired everything we needed directly on snow was super easy. Main Lift lines were pretty busy but then headed around to blue cow for some great intermediate and advanced runs heaps less people too. Later in the day worked around to other side of resort for some great solid blue runs. All in all resort is pretty easy to navigate with plenty of signs and maps. And some great natural terrain to enjoy.

name: Mirko Gozzo
review_text:
All considered, I enjoyed Perisher. There are tons of lifts and the natural terrain is great for having fun snowboarding. During the week I was here, snowpark were in decent shape and my son and I really played a lot. The lift are a bit outdated. Considering the constant wind, I'd expect the lift to have the wind cover but none has them. T-bar are also so 80s and there are plenty here.
Food at the different place is awful. I've never said in my life "I miss home because I need some fruit or something that is not fried"... Loads of potential though. Hope the new investor starts with some needed upgrade soon.

name: hkumara
review_text:
Awesome.

name: Mitchell Close
review_text: Not bad. Incredibly expensive. Can often be a ridiculous wait in the lift line, especially early morning when you're stuck at front valley for your first few runs, but there's so many lifts you can almost always find an empty one. Good variety of terrain too.

review_text: First experience to be in a ski resort. This place is beautiful. You can hire ski equipments and get a learning session. The place is huge and have many foods. I tried Kebab which is halal and tasty.

great place to be.

review_text: Perisher has the best terrain parks in the Southern Hemisphere hands down. It makes the place a bit of a pro-shred gong show, and the local scene can be a bit too-cool-for-school, but the staff is kind, the snow isn't half bad and the parks are creative. So that's that!

name: warren payne
review_text:
The resort needs some facilities modernized.
The car parking area is in poor condition. Some of the food outlets are selling below standard meals.

name: Ryan Franklin
review_text: In my opinion Perisher is the best ski resort in Australia. It has a large quantity of good runs for all abilities and it's staff are component and friendly. That said I urge people to consider the true cost of sking at Perisher. For example the cost of buying a lift pass is extremely high. For my wife and I to ski for three days it cost us $780 just for lift passes. Couple that with the cost of buying a three day pass just to get your car into the park costing nearly $90. The food on site will also cost you a arm and a leg, a hot chocolate will be nearly $10, a bottle of water $6 and the food is of mediocre taste and quality. To add insult to injury they have no facilities to enable you to be self contained so you have to rely on there on site catering facilities. Then you have the cost of hiring your gear and paying for accommodation on top of all that. I assure you that by the time you ad all of this up you may wonder why on earth it cost so much. Consider your options, it may be almost cheaper to go over seas to do the same thing in Japan where the powder can be sensational. In summary Perisher is a great ski resort but it comes at a rich mans price I'm not sure the value for money is really there.

review_text:
It's a good mountain!
But a 15 year old is classified as and adult so a 1 day lift pass and tube there and return was $164 and that is ridiculous!
I don't see how a 15 year old is an adult, so I don't think I'm going to be going there again.
Don't recommend it if you are 15 !
Ps: that's why I board Thredbo and that's why I'm a season pass holder at Thredbo because if you are 15 you are classified as a child, and they don't rip you off!

name: Kenny
review_text: trash, staff rude af
review_translated_text: trash, trash can

name: guan guanxiongxian
review_text: Nice place, lots fun.

name: John Gobel
review_text: Massive Alpine Ressort, so many things to explore, unbeatable views and friendly staff. Never had so much fun at a diffrent Ski Ressort!

name: Jacob Meyers
review_text: Well planned snow park with friendly staff and great food in the pubs.

name: Sharon Hu
review_text:
I had this terrible experience with serge's cafe Smiggin today. After ordering $50 worth of food I went back to the counter wanting to find out where I can find tomato sauce for hot chips I ordered for my kids. While I was quietly waiting the guy at the counter suddenly screamed out rudely to me" go away, we don't have hot water!!!!" I was totally in shock then realised as I was holding a coffee in my hand, the guy assumed I was asking for hot water like lots of Asian tourists would ask?I don't think there is anything wrong with asking for hot water even I do ask for it?! But in this situation I was extremely upset to be screamed at without even saying anything?!So I explained to the guy that I only tried to ask where to find tomato sauce. The guy then answered rudly "well I made a judgement call then!!". There was no intention of any apology I was really upset therefore I raised my voice asking him to apologise! The guy looked angry and impatient but what's worse was that as the same time he handed me the tomato sauce he threw my $4 change ( 2 coins)on the ground!!! On purpose!! In front of hundred people!!'
I picked up my money and walked away. Feeling humiliated and angry!
I am still in total shock as our tourists guide says we Chinese bring so many tourists each year to Smiggin and this is how we get treated?!? Most of Chinese of my parents generation can't speak English they would have just walked away in this situation  .I wonder if that's the reason they think they can be rude to us however they like but if we do complain they would just throw the money on the ground and ask us to go away?!!!

Unbelievable!!'!
Shame on you bullies!!!

name: Jake Xerri
review_text: If you come on a good season, you're going to have a blast. Lots of runs ranging from the smooth and wind to the long and windy. On a sunny day you'd almost consider going down in a shirt, it's so pleasant. Just bring money and lots of it. If you're planning in advance, do yourself a favor and book early to save some cash.

name: Phil Mackay
review_text: Good open terrain. Great for exploring off piste.

name: Peter LIN
review_text: Nice place & easy to learning

name: saurabh sibal
review_text: Great resort area with lots of lifts and nice groomed runs catering for all abilities. Be sure to visit Guthega when you go there.

name: Lesya Muscat
review_text:
1. Purchased private lesson with instructor at 11am for 1pm.
The weather was absolutely bad, raining (not snowing! ), strong wind, etc.
I came back 5 mins later and said that kids are already wet through,  they don't want to do anything outside and till 1pm they will be sick, angry and cold! So i asked for refund. No refund was given. I asked to change the dates, they wanted to charge me more.
No customer service,  all about getting more money!

2. I came with 2 kids: 1 - 4years old; 2 - 8years old. They had never done skiing  before. So obviously they were not going to ski on ALL 47 LIFTS!!! And obviously i had to stay with them teaching the moves.  It's absolutely ridiculous to make kids and parents pay for the whole resort lifts and especially knowing that a parent is stuck with them (no, i did not want to pay ~150$ per kid per day and leave them in the school, because i came to perisher to spend time with my children while school holidays are on! So we enjoy being together!)
I had to spend ~130$ just to be able to go on kid's "magic carpet" with my little ones to be able to hold them while they are sliding  (falling) down. Is that fair??? Did I get to enjoy the whole perisher lifts?? NO!!!
It's all about making as much money as you can!!! Monopoly!

Here is the great suggestion! Why don't you make 1 main 8 seats lift and magic carpet for newbies/kids/parents (guardian ) so we can pay acceptable fee so we don't regret coming here spending all this money for what? For service i did not get?? Would we want now to come back to perisher and recommend you! ? ....

Just make separate coded pass card that works only on 1-2 lifts so people feel that you are not trying to rip them off!!!

name: Jim Cruwys
review_text: Really good, so many runs and area to explore.

name: Captain Sparklez
review_text: Soooooo fun!

name: Todd Berlin
review_text: Great resort for families. Lots of runs and a few trickier ones. You need a little luck to have plenty of snow but if there is, it's awesome. Mid station cafe is the bomb - so warm with tasty food!

name: Nathan Dearling
review_text: Heaps of activities, lots of ski lifts and great facilities

name: Abhie Gupta
review_text: Beautiful and wonderful for skiing.

review_text: Awesome place for skiing. Had a great weekend away. Drove up from Melbourne.

review_text: Ao Zhou Zui Da Hua Xue Chang
review_translated_text: Australia's largest ski resort

review_text: It was pouring rain and most of the lifts were shut, but it was a great place to drink beers with my friend Brian

name: CY Lim
review_text: First time skiing, nice location and have all different track

name: Vs C
review_text: Massive terrain with lots of traverse and shot runs. More suitable for ski however they do have few good terrain parks. Good off piste runs especially between trees. Lots of between runs area to explore after a good snow fall.
response_from_owner_text:
We're glad to hear that you had a great time here.
Hope to see you again this upcoming winter!

name: Ashlee Davidson
review_text: Great place to learn how to ski
response_from_owner_text: Glad you had a great time Ashlee! We hope to see you at Perisher again in 2016!

name: Khan Mohammad Salem Sabir
review_text: Don't forget to take your gear while you go there alone or with family. It was so freezing I felt like my fingers might get cracked and face became blue. Huge car park and mind blowing snow view. You have to take rent chain for sedan car front tyres before you go there.

review_text: Great Resort

name: Pochie Dixon
review_text: We had a great time! 1 day trip is not enough, i'll be back next winter season and that's for sure! ;)

review_text: Great resort but don't recommend the lessons for snowboarding - the instructor was nice but I learned more from YouTube about what to do in boarding.
